did.abstract: The Albert Kahn Family Papers include the personal correspondence of Albert, his wife Ernestine Krolik Kahn, his son Edgar Adolph Kahn, and his daughter Ruth Kahn Rothman, miscellaneous materials which document the personal and professional lives of family members, and photographic images from the 1870s to 2015.

bioghist.p: As America's most influential industrial architect, Albert Kahn revolutionized the health and safety conditions of early twentieth-century factories and worked closely with Henry Ford to implement his vision of the assembly line at the Highland Park and River Rouge automobile plants. Kahn pioneered the use of reinforced concrete, non-intrusive steel structures, natural ventilation and glass building skins to respond to the changing functional needs of the American factory. His pragmatism, ability to listen to the needs of the client and experimentation with innovative building technologies resulted in a new industrial architecture, which inspired the development of European Modernism by Walter Gropius, Mies van der Rohe and Le Corbusier. Hugely versatile in his design capabilities and strongly interested in historic architecture, Kahn also produced many commercial and institutional icons in Detroit and at the University of Michigan, including the Fisher Building, Detroit Athletic Club, General Motors Building, Hill Auditorium, Angell Hall, William L. Clements Library and Burton Memorial Carillon Tower. This most prolific of American architects built over 2000 projects in his lifetime, including 521 factories in Russia between 1929 and 1932, and in 1938 was constructing 19% of all architect-designed industrial facilities in the United States. When he died in 1942, he had signed defense contracts totaling $200 million for the construction of the Willow Run Bomber Plant and naval bases in Honolulu, Midway Island, Puerto Rico and Kodak, Alaska, among other war-time facilities.

In 1896, Kahn married Ernestine Krolik, the daughter of Adolph Krolik, who was a successful dry goods merchant and a client of the young architect. A graduate of the University of Michigan in 1892, Ernestine was a talented gardener and interior designer, who often advised Albert on matters of color and fabric selection. When speaking of her parents, their daughter Rosalie Kahn Butzel said years later that "they complemented each other wonderfully."[1] Albert and Ernestine had two other daughters, Lydia and Ruth, and one son, Edgar (1900-1985). "Eddie" became the first scorer and captain of the University of Michigan hockey team, graduating from the University Medical School in 1924. From 1949 to 1971, he served as the Chairman of Neurosurgery at the University of Michigan Hospital (designed by his father in 1919).
1) Richard Bak, "Blueprint for Detroit," HOUR Detroit (May, 2000, reprinted by Albert Kahn Associates, Inc.), p. 2.

arrangement.p: The Albert Kahn Family Papers are arranged in three series, named for the donors of the materials: Kahn Family Papers, Carol Kahn, collector; Kahn Family Papers, William R. Brashear and Ruth Brashear Carrigan, collectors; and Kahn Family Papers, Elizabeth (Betsy) Kahn Lehndorff, collector.

scopecontent.p: The Kahn Family Papers have come to the library from four sources: from Carol Kahn, the granddaughter of Albert and Ernestine Kahn and daughter of Edgar A. Kahn; from William R. Brashear, who was married to Albert's and Ernestine's granddaughter, Lydia Rothman Brashear; from William Brashear's daughter, Ruth Brashear Carrigan; and from Edgar Kahn's daughter, Elizabeth Kahn Lehndorff. The Albert Kahn Family Papers received from Carol Kahn include letters and photographs which contribute to our understanding of Kahn's relationship with his wife, children and grandchildren. The materials also illuminate the distinguished military and professional careers of his son Edgar (1900-1985), who served as Chairman of Neurosurgery at the University of Michigan Hospital from 1949 to 1971. The papers received from William R. Brashear and his daughter Ruth Carrigan document the personal and professional lives of Albert and Ernestine Kahn, Ruth Kahn Rothman, Edward E. Rothman and other members of the extended Kahn family, including Albert Kahn's granddaughters, Josephine Rothman Treutner and Lydia Rothman Brashear. Mr. Brashear's collection also encompasses family letters and photographs, which are contained in his book, Albert Kahn and His Family in Peace and War, published by the Bentley Historical Library in 2006. The materials donated by Elizabeth (Betsy) Lehndorff relate to her recent careers as a journalist in Colorado and as a jewelry artist in Alpena, Michigan.

scopecontent.p: The first series, Carol Kahn, collector, encompasses four sub-series, related to the lives of Albert and Ernestine Kahn, Mollie Kahn Fuchs, Edgar A. Kahn and Carol Kahn. Researchers will find a number of interesting early letters within the Albert and Ernestine Kahn Correspondence sub-series. While the letters from Albert number only four, his letter to his sister-in-law Amy of 11/9/1900 is of particular interest. In this hand-written piece of correspondence, Kahn recounts his delight in visiting Paris, Genoa, and Florence in 1891 and includes a sketch of an Italian arch. He also expresses pride and delight in his baby son, Edgar. Two late letters of 6/26/1940 and 7/17/1942 to Edgar, who was posted for military duty in Spain and Little Rock, Arkansas, are also significant. In these documents, Kahn describes his own war defense work and expresses concern for his son's welfare. He gives us a glimpse of paternal emotion when he ends the 1940 letter with these words to Eddie: "You mean everything to all of us." The four letters to Kahn in this sub-series include two from his brother Julius (one dated 1/14/1900), with whom he collaborated on the use of reinforced concrete in structural design. And a letter from his first partner Alexander Buel Trowbridge (10/17/1898), who had recently become the dean of the Cornell University College of Architecture, documents this early professional relationship.

Within the Albert and Ernestine Correspondence sub-series, the letters written by Kahn's future wife Ernestine Krolik, at the age of 16, give researchers a view of the personality of this intelligent, young woman, who shows herself to be cultured, confident and family-oriented. Twenty-one letters were written by Ernestine during her summer visit in St. Paul, Minnesota, from 6/29/1885 to 9/1/1885. They were addressed to her mother, sister Bell, brother Day and father Adolph Krolik, a dry goods merchant who would later become a client of Albert Kahn. In addition to her descriptions of her train trips to such tourist destinations as Lake Johanna, White Bear Lake and Lake St. Croix, she provides detailed walking-tour portraits of the cities of St. Paul and Minneapolis in 1885. Her letters show her to have a game sense of adventure, as well as a strong devotion to her parents, whose "kindness and warm-heartedness" she praises. Included in the letters to Ernestine is a 1942 Western Union telegram from V. A. Vernin, a Russian architect-academician, expressing "sympathy in connection with the death of your husband Mr. Albert Kahn, who rendered us great service in designing a number of large plants and helped us to assimilate the American experience in the sphere of [the] building industry."

scopecontent.p: The Mollie Fuchs Kahn sub-series contains her "Memoirs" (1937), a very important first-hand telling of the story of the Kahn children's first decades in America with parents, Joseph and Rosalie Kahn. Researchers seeking to understand the early years of Albert Kahn and the challenges of this hard-working immigrant family will find the "Memoirs" of great interest.

The Edgar Adolph Kahn sub-series contains a large body of material related to the personal life and illustrious medical career of Albert's and Ernestine's only son (1900-1985). These documents, both textual and visual, offer a rich perspective on Edgar's childhood, World War II military experience, medical career as Chief of Neurosurgery at University of Michigan Hospital (1949-1971), family, travels and writings. As a whole, they flesh out a picture of his strengths as a leader and his relationships as a son, husband and father.

Letters within the Edgar Kahn sub-series range from congratulatory notes to his parents at the time of his birth to his correspondence with his friends and colleagues, including his mentor Dr. Max M. Peet, in the Neurosurgery Department at the University of Michigan. The letters to Dr. Peet describe Edgar's further medical training in London in 1936 and his military service at Kennedy General Hospital in Memphis, Tennessee, as World War II came to an end. Peet's letters to Edgar in 1942 and 1945 give researchers a view of the changes and challenges at University Hospital during the war years. Letters from other physicians document Edgar Kahn's stature in the field of neurosurgery. Personal correspondence with his parents during World War II are also of interest.

Edgar Kahn's illustrious neurosurgery career at the University of Michigan and in national organizations is well documented in this sub-series, with early notes on his practice (1926), transcription of his speeches and professional journal submissions. Newspaper articles about his medical career, his distinguished service during the war and even his hockey prowess, while a student at the University of Michigan in 1921, give additional perspective on his diverse achievements in medicine and other areas.

The photographs in the Edgar Kahn sub-series pertain to his youth, his school years at Andover and the University of Michigan, his European travels, his military service and his medical career in the neurosurgical operating room. These often intimate glimpses of Edgar in various states of relaxation with colleagues, friends and his wife Rose are significant in providing researchers with a sense of the strong relationships in Edgar's life. The audio-visual materials in this sub-series range from an important reel-to-reel-taped interview, which his daughter Carol conducted with her father in 1978, to audio tapes of one of Edgar's professional speeches and of his memorial service in 1985.

scopecontent.p: The Carol Kahn sub-series includes a collection of newspaper articles, letters and photographs describing the efforts of a group of Ann Arbor citizens to "Save Old Main," The University of Michigan Hospital, which Albert Kahn designed and built in 1921 and in which her father practiced neurosurgery. Carol was active in this 1989 preservation campaign, which succeeded in saving the entry arch of her grandfather's historic hospital and in establishing the Albert Kahn Commemorative Art Project at the hospital.

scopecontent.p: The William R. Brashear and Ruth Brashear Carrigan, collectors series is comprised of files named for the family members with papers in the collection, including Albert Kahn, Ernestine Krolik Kahn, Ruth Kahn Rothman, Edward E. Rothman, Mrs. Eli Rothman, Lydia Kahn Winston Malbin, Rosalie Kahn Butzel, Josephine Rothman Treutner, Lydia Rothman Brashear, William R. Brashear, Ruth Brashear Carrigan, Lydia Brashear Tiede, and Elizabeth (Betsy) Kahn Lehndorff.

Of particular interest within the Ruth Kahn Rothman file are twelve folders of letters written by Edward E. Rothman, while she was a student at Emma Willard School in 1922, and later, during his service in Northern Africa and France in World War II. Also of significance are letters from her parents, written between 1923 and 1929, which give insight into Albert's and Ernestine's relationship with their daughter. Newspaper articles about her marriage and her community service over many years further enrich the perspective on Ruth's life.

The Edward E. Rothman file includes his official Army papers and newspaper articles about his assignments abroad during World War II. Biographical materials in the form of articles, letters and press releases illuminate the married lives of Ruth and Edward, as well as his professional career and philanthropic activities with Michigan State University and the Detroit Institute of Arts Founders' Society. Photographs of the Kahn and Rothman families are also of interest, including a set of slides (with viewer), taken in 1956, with a popular, stereoscopic camera of the day.

Miscellaneous articles about Kahn's daughters, Rosalie Butzel and Lydia Winston Malbin, and granddaughters, Josephine Rothman Treutner, Lydia Rothman Brashear and Elizabeth Kahn Lehndorff, further enrich the intergenerational family picture. The files of the two Rothman daughters, Jospehine and Lydia, contain their wedding albums and more stereoscopic slides of these events, from 1956 and 1961. Because Lydia was Mr. Brashear's wife, his collection contains a few letters from her grandfather, Albert Kahn, and documents pertaining to her early equestrian activities.

Included in the William R. Brashear file is a copy of a book which he wrote in 1977, entitled, The Gorgon's Head , and his important volume, Albert Kahn and His Family in Peace and War , which was published by the Bentley Historical Library in 2006. Mr. Brashear was a literature scholar, with degrees from the University of Michigan and Princeton University. He also practiced law in Livonia, Michigan. He preserved the collection of family materials which his wife Lydia Rothman Brashear had amassed from her grandparents, mother and father and used them as primary source material in the writing of his book on Albert Kahn. The original letters and photographs are included in the Albert and Ernestine Kahn, Ruth Kahn Rothman, Edward E. Rothman and Lydia Rothman Brashear file of his collection here. He donated these documents to the Bentley Historical Library after the completion of his book and with the help of his daughter Ruth Brashear Carrigan, after his death in 2014. Copies of the letters and photographs which were used in his book are included within the William Brashear file.

The Albert Kahn sub-series contains letters from his wife and daughter Lydia, while traveling aboard the ship, "Mauretania," in 1923, as well as his obituary and documents related to the celebration of his enormous legacy, after his death. Obituaries and newspaper articles in the Ernestine Krolik Kahn sub-series describe some of her social and community involvements.

scopecontent.p: The series, Kahn Family Papers, Elizabeth (Betsy) Kahn Lehndorff, collector, is named for the granddaughter of Albert and Ernestine Kahn and daughter of Edgar A. Kahn, who has donated materials related to her own career, as a journalist and jewelry artist. It is expected that the third and fourth generations of Kahns will continue to keep the record of this accomplished family alive through ongoing donations of materials.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The Albert Kahn Papers, donated by his firm Albert Kahn Associates, Inc. in 2003, include 13 linear feet of correspondence, transcripts of speeches, newspaper articles and construction photographs of many of Kahn's most significant buildings. In addition, almost 10,000 original, ink-on-linen construction drawings of 200 of his industrial, commercial, institutional and residential projects are housed in flat-file drawers. The narrative and visual documents in this large collection give researchers the opportunity to study many aspects of the master architect's career and life, from his personal views on industrial architecture contained in his speeches, to the drawings which preserve his iconic buildings for posterity on paper.
